results.title: Running water: landform evolution
results.creator_credit: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 20 of Series “Earth revealed”.
Recognizes the roles human activity can play in itensifying or reducing flood danger. Looks at how rivers cut into landscapes to produce wonders like the Grand Canyon and the formation of deltas and lakes where water and sediment is collected. This episode also looks at how geologists and engineers are tackling the problem of accumulation of silt and sediment in the Mississippi River where three rivers in the delta region are converging.

results.title: Running water: erosion & deposition
results.creator_credit: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 19 of Series “Earth revealed”.
What do rivers do? The power or velocity of river flow is responsible for some of the most unique sculpting of landforms on the planet. Running water transports sediments and deposits it at river mouths and deltas as well as abrasively smoothing and wearing away bedrock on its course. Geologists study the ways rivers flow and meander in order to solve problems of flooding and silting as well as assiting engineers in the construction of dams and dykes in order to improve flow of water.

results.title: Bette Davis' eyes
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Filmstruck Series”.
What makes a star? Clips from a host of films look at the legendary stars - Sarah Bernhardt, Shirley Temple, Joan Crawford, Errol Flynn and Bette Davis. This program is episode seven in the ten part documentary, “Filmstruck”, which considers the impact of cinema on the social and personal life of the viewing audience.

results.title: Metamorphic rocks
results.creator_credit: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 18 of Series “Earth revealed”.
The process of metamorphism changes the structure and composition of rocks; an atomic shuffling which results in change. Metamorphism for example is responsible for changing limestone into marble. There are two types of metamorphism; contact metamorphism resulting from a cooling process and regional metamorphism which is the result of tectonic activity. As a consequence of this process, many rare minerals can be formed.

results.title: The Body Malleable
results.material_description: video, interactive software, mixed media, colour and sound
results.brief_description: The Body Malleable is an intimate interactive work where a custom built ‘gromit’ is physically engaged with by the viewer to create a display combining digital animation and synchronised audio in the installation space. The custom interface, placed on a desk for one viewer to interact with at a time, is internally configured with a 100 key keyboard broken up and reassembled within the spherical space. Darkness within the pod, the viewer is asked to insert their finger into a small opening to probe the key board lining. The keys pressed act as switches to key events programmed into Director and thus set off a series of audio-visual responses via surround sound and a single circular screen projection to create an intimate experiential space determined by the audiences interaction.
results.description: The Body Malleable is an intimate interactive work where a custom built ‘gromit’ is physically engaged with by the viewer to create a display combining digital animation and synchronised audio in the installation space. results.title: Being True Blue
results.creator_credit: Kay Donovan, Australia. Office of Multicultural Affairs and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
This documentary explores what it means to be an Australian citizen and just what a new citizen is welcome to. In interviews with historians, social planners and ordinary people, ‘Being True Blue’ looks behind the facade of the national anthem, the sports hero, the bushman and the other cheap barometers of identity.

results.title: Poor Man's Cinema
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Filmstruck Series”.
It’s what countries like Australia produce - documentaries! John Baxter, well-known Australian film historian and cinema critic, looks at the renaissance of the ‘60s as well as the Hollywood wartime documentaries, and their effect on the evolution of cinema.

results.title: Sedimentry rocks
results.creator_credit: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 17 of Series “Earth revealed”.
Illustrates the importance of sedimentary rocks in understanding earth’s history. Sediment is the result of chemical and mechanical weathering assisted by erosion, water, ice and biological activities such as movement of dunes. Sedimentary rocks hold much of the fossil evidence which provide insight into the evolution of life on earth. The building up of sedimentary layers results in the formation of structures such as reefs and formations like limestone caves.

results.title: Days of Stargazey Pie
results.creator_credit: Margaret Haselgrove, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service and Australia. Office of Multicultural Affairs
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
Cornish descendants, a tourist guide and a historian talk about the contribution that the Cornish miners made to the development of the South Australian copper mines at Burra and Moonta. We also look at some of their traditions which have been handed down from generation to generation in this ‘Little Cornwall”
